metadata.metaValue: The solver assumes a constant number of sources and points. This is not a limit of the underlying operators, just this solver compound. The benefit of this design is that properties can be changed on input sources on the fly, and the solver doesn't have to worry about which updated point goes to which solved point.
Collision shape based off bounding box
Point cloud collision shape based on the mesh's point poisition
Point cloud collision shape based on scatter
We can scatter points on the mesh for a sparser point cloud ie. better performance (at the cost of some accuracy).
Mesh and Mesh (BVH) have limitations as dynamic rigid bodies. These work best for kinematic and static bodies

Compound shapes are the best option for concave collisions with dynamic rigid bodies. Auto compound uses btCompoundFromGimpactShape, which is accurate, but its children do not implement scale, margin, and the resulting shape is often very expensive. A custom compound shape algorithm is needed.

The brain of the graph is 'simulate_bullet'. All rigid bodies are the same so there's no dedicate 'colliders' input, instead these would just be rigid bodies in 'static' mode.

The output geo type will always be instances, because this is what the solver opperates on internally. Instances can be used as a source directly, but they should be passed through a 'source_rigid_body_instances' which sets their physical properties. Collision shapes are set at the mesh level using 'set_collision_shape', any point that instances the mesh will also instance it's collision shape. If the mesh has no collision shape property, it will be computed automatically using the fallback shape type.

This example however uses meshes which are sourced with 'source_rigid_bodies', this converts a mesh array into a single instances object. For setting per body properties we could use 'source_rigid_body_instances' afterwards, but a generally more convient option is to use 'prep_rigid_body_mesh'.
Basic RBD example with full mesh collision
